newsitem.title: UK: NWE gas oil premiums ease as demand stays thin.
newsitem.headline: NWE gas oil premiums ease as demand stays thin.

text.p: NWE gas oil premiums eased on Tuesday as prompt demand remained slack but IPE futures strengthened, pushing outright prices higher, traders said.
Heating oil premiums were $1-$2 a tonne weaker, while diesel held firm. Feb IPE gas oil was up $2 at $201.75 by 1300 GMT, playing catch-up to crude's overnight gains.
Slow barge demand trimmed ARA premiums with a Feb 1-15 refinery barge trading mid-morning at Feb IPE +$3 fob Rotterdam, $1.50 off Monday's levels.
"There's no sense of urgency, demand has just filtered away," said one barge trader.
Another trader said German buying interest was lacking, depressed by high stock levels and some disruption to traffic because of ice.
Cargo business was also slack with German heating oil pegged around Feb IPE +$6 for Feb 1-15 and FOD around Feb IPE +$5.50-$6.50 for the same period.
Early February Russians were offered at Feb IPE +$4, about $1 weaker than Monday, but were not attracting any interest.
Diesel barges were on offer at Feb IPE +$14 fob ARA for Feb 1-15, also against little interest, traders said.
